have found the earliest DNA evidence of human habitation in North America has
been added to the National Register of Historic Places....
articles.title: Cave containing earliest human DNA dubbed historic (The Arizona Republic)

A new paper takes a hard look at why cheetah populations are declining
rapidly, despite their being the fleetest creatures around. Trace has the
details.

articles.author: Guardian: None Given
articles.summary:
Guardian: Ebola is spreading at the rate of five new cases an hour in Sierra
Leone, according to figures released as world leaders and experts on disease
control gathered in London to discuss the outbreak. The figures from Save the
Children showed there were 765 new cases last week in the west African country
alone, but only 327 hospital beds to treat infected patients. The charity said
the “terrifying” rate of the spread of the disease was outstripping medical
supplies and threatened a breakdown of Sierra...
articles.title: Ebola infecting five new people every hour in Sierra Leone, figures show (climateark)

articles.summary:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Scientists have devised a new map of the Earth's
seafloor using satellite data, revealing massive underwater scars and
thousands of previously uncharted sea mountains residing in some of the
deepest, most remote reaches of the world's oceans.
articles.title: Global seafloor map reveals stunning details of Earth's depths (reuters)

articles.author: Elizabeth Howell
articles.summary:
TORONTO, CANADA - Should E.T. finally give Earth a ring, it's not only
important to understand what the message says but why it is being sent, a
speaker at a talk about extraterrestrials urged this week. This requires
understanding about alien social behavior, also known as sociology. "We keep
complaining about the fact that we […]
articles.title: How Do Aliens Think? We Need To Learn About Their Biology First, Analyst Argues (Universe Today)

articles.title: Nobel Crystal Ball: Predictions for the 2014 Prize in Physics (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
An iceplant, from a region of high diversity in South Africa, is overtopping
and killing a native shrub on the New Zealand coast, a region with far less
diversity. Dov Sax of Brown University and Jason Fridley of Syracuse
University aren't proposing a novel idea to explain species invasiveness. In
fact, Charles Darwin articulated it first. What's new about Sax and Fridley's
"Evolutionary Imbalance Hypothesis" (EIH) is that they've tested it using
quantifiable evidence and report in _Global Ecology and Biogeography_ that the
EIH works well.
articles.title: On invasive species, Darwin had it right all along, study shows (Biologynews)

articles.summary:
A fading sense of smell in older adults is a strong predictor of whether
they’ll die in the next five years, research has revealed.
articles.title: Your ability to detect five scents in old age can predict how long you'll live (Science Alert)
